column4: If I compile and install some libraries from source code in my Ubuntu would be any problems later If I upgrade my Ubuntu to it's next release?
possibly
they (binaries or libraries, so files and ...) will be overwritten during upgrade (installing other versions of deb files), is it true?
as i said, it could be a problem and there could not be.
as i asked, is there a secure way to deal with this (for example some app that checks for this type of installed libs during upgrade)?
no there isn't
and what do you do in these conditions? just remember to "make remove" the source version before upgrading?
as long as the app isn't used by the base system you don't have to worry more than the app itself stops working
libraries?!
libraries can be used in many other apps
you can always, not upgrade. and dont worry about it
do you suggest not upgrading at all?
depends if you want the upgrades or not. and if you want them more than risking breaking a library.
i do not suggest not upgrading at all, i'm just putting things in perspective
is this a bug/problem/weakness of linux? heard if some people are working on it?
this is not a weakness of linux, it's a weakness of the progress of upgrading. it's in _ALL_ operating systems.
agree that its not linux's fault, maybe packaging systems (deb/rpms)
no, it's not any package systems fault, it's the fault that you are using something outside of apt-get annd then run a upgrade that changes how things work.
and the library hasn't changed to fit with the upgrade.
you can only blaim this on not doing things the right way.
but if you have the source, usually a recompile fixes any potential problems.
what is the library you want btw?
